notesStmt.note: Year determined by Routes List: BBWW performed in Chicago, Illinois, on July 25-30, 1898. According to Bonner, William "Okie" Synder was WFC's ranch manager who had taken 160 acres near Irma Flats. Horace C. Alger (1857-1906) was a banker from Sheridan, Wyoming, mayor of Sheridan in 1889, and candidate for Governor of Wyoming in 1898. Cody, Beck and Alger were responsible for developing the Shoshone Irrigation Company.

div1.p: Those Preists3 want their deeds to their Lots— I wish you would let me know if you are now ready and will make them out for them?

Snyder4 writes me you have gone South to work for Alger— not but what I approoveapprove of it. But I cantcan't beleivebelieve that you would leave until the water was again runingrunning. If you have left our business just at this critical time— Its not right And I will so notify the Co. I hope itsit's not true—

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West performed in Chicago, Illinois, on July 25-30, 1898.
Note 2: The year is not inscribed but is 1898.
Note 3: "Priests" is reference to the Chicago clergy who promoted land sales and influenced their Polish and Bavarian parishioners to homestead in the Big Horn Basin.
Note 4: "Snyder" is William "Okie" Snyder (b.1856), William F. Cody's ranch manager who had taken 160 acres near Irma Flats.
